awd_titl_txt: Algebraic Geometric Approaches to Biological Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
The Human Genome project and subsequent developments have given us unprecedented knowledge of the genes and proteins within us.  There is much anticipation that this knowledge will translate into substantial improvements in human health and well-being.  A central challenge, however, is the enormous complexity that we encounter at the molecular level.  It is not merely that we have 20,000 genes but that the machinery that regulates each gene is itself extraordinarily complex with, in the case of some genes, billions of potential states.  Moreover, when the gene is expressed as a protein, each protein may itself become modified so that it too can exist in many different states, which may have profoundly different consequences.  This project will use two mathematical formalisms developed in previous work -- the "linear framework" and the method of "invariants" -- that have been shown to be capable of rising above the complexity and eliciting general principles.  The investigators will use these formalisms to analyze two focus problems in which the underlying complexity has proved intractable: (1) "epigenetic" mechanisms in gene regulation, which play a central role in how the environment influences gene expression, and (2) decision-making switches based on protein modification states, which play a central role in controlling cellular behavior.  A key aspect of the project is the involvement of undergraduate students from the mathematical and physical sciences, especially students from under-represented groups.  The project will act as pipeline to motivate such students towards research in the biological and bio-medical sciences, a strategy that contributed substantially to the success of previous work. 

The biochemical reactions within cells are generally assumed to follow the principle of mass action -- the rate of a reaction is the product of the concentrations of the reactants -- so that their behavior can be represented by a polynomial dynamical system.  The steady states of a network of reactions are therefore solutions to a set of polynomial equations and form an algebraic variety.  The investigators have pioneered the use of methods from algebraic geometry in the study of biochemical networks, leading to the introduction of the "linear framework" and the method of "invariants," both of which can distill biological principles in the face of molecular complexity.  This project will further develop these approaches by attacking two major focus problems.  First, the investigators will analyze the behavior of protein modification switches, which are central motifs in regulating cellular signaling pathways and cell behavior, and will characterize them in terms of their invariants.  Second, the role of energy-dissipating, epigenetic mechanisms in gene regulation will be analyzed.  In previous work, the investigators showed that energy dissipation leads to a profound increase in complexity through the phenomenon of history-dependence.  Methods for interpreting that complexity and identifying how energy-dissipation contributes to environmental modulation of gene expression will be developed.

por.por_cntn:
The scientific goal of this project was to use tools from pure mathematics to study molecular networks in biological cells. Its broader goal was to undertake this research in part through a program of mentoring undergraduate summer students, with a focus on those from under-represented communities.

One of the major challenges in studying molecular networks is their overwhelming complexity. There are around 20,000 genes in the human genome but this number gives little hint of the true complexity. Each gene may give rise to multiple versions of a protein and, when these proteins work in the cell, they may become chemically modified on multiple sites. Such modifications are a key mechanism in the cell's response to changing conditions. For example, the tumor-suppressor protein p53, which is often mutated in cancers, has over 100 sites of modification. This means that a single molecule of p53 can have as many as 1030 potential states. Of course, not all these states are present at at any time but the enormous number of possibilities have made the rigorous analysis of protein behavior extremely challenging.

Pure mathematics, especially graph theory and algebraic geometry, offers new tools for handling molecular complexity. For example, we have used these methods to show that, when modification processes reach a steady state, the effective complexity is governed not by the number of modification sites but by the number of enzymes that regulate the modifications, which may be as few as 100. The consequent extreme reduction from 1030 to 102 converts the previously intractable problem to one that is amenable to rigorous analysis. We have built on this to analyze the conditions under which modification systems exhibit robust switching between different patterns of modification. We have found that the conditions are far more restrictive than expected, suggesting that modification systems may require additional mechanisms to achieve robust switching. Switching networks of this kind are now being considered as potential designs in synthetic biology and we anticipate our work will provide a rigorous mathematical foundation for such biological engineering.

Another important challenge in studying molecular networks is to understand the role of energy expenditure. Energy is fundamental to life but the way in which it influences information processing by molecular networks has been difficult to unravel, in part because the fundamental physics is still not worked out. Here again, tools from pure mathematics have been vital in analyzing these systems. One of our key findings is that, depending on the information processing task, there is a fundamental limit to how well the task can be undertaken when energy is not expended. We call this limit a Hopfield barrier in honor of the physicist John Hopfield who first pointed this out for the accuracy of DNA replication during heredity. We have discovered that the Hopfield barrier for the sharpness of a steady-state input-output response is given by the well-known Hill function, which is widely used to fit experimental data but has never been thought to have any deeper significance. An important implication of this finding, in the light of the latest experimental data, is that certain genes must be regulated beyond the Hopfield barrier and are therefore consuming energy. Independent experiments are now being undertaken to test this finding, which suggests that our understanding of how genes are being regulated must now be updated.

The broader goal of this project was to undertake the research in part through a program of summer internships for undergraduate students, with a focus on students from under-represented groups. The program aims to mentor students into research at the mathematics-biology interface and provide continuing support to them in their future careers. The program also provides invaluable experience for lab members in the art of mentoring. This NSF award supported 13 students of whom 5/13 were female and 7/13 were form under-represented groups. Students work on projects that are part of the lab's research and often make significant contributions, with some students becoming co-authors on published papers. For example, one of our students made an important discovery about input-output sharpness. When energy is not being expended, sharpness is known to arise from cooperative interactions between different input binding sites. However, beyond the Hopfield barrier, our student discovered that a single binding site can yield unlimited sharpness. This is very unexpected and has opened a new direction of research for the lab. Our student will become a first author on the paper which describes her findings. The summer program has been successful at attracting excellent students from diverse communities to the mathematics-biology interface and has played a key role in our lab's research.
